photos.author: Chinese Tallow Seed pods © DanielCD 2005 [Attribution-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported (CC BY-SA 3.0) https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/], from Wikimedia Commons
A.A. Agosta 2003. School of Renewable Natural Resources LSU AgDCenter. Picture take from http://www.rnr.lsu.edu

invasion: native to the southern half of China and Japan
extensively planted as ornamental
forms homogeneous stands displacing native plants
alters nutrient cycles (encourages eutrophication) from the rapid decay of its leaves
favours non-native arthropods
competes with cavity-nesting birds for nest sites
behavior: rapid growth
deciduous
prolific seeding
tolerance to drought, flooding and salinity
dispersal of seeds by birds and water
trees can remain productive for 100 years
confusion: None
appearance: tree, up to 16 m high
exudes a milky sap
leaves simple, alternate, broadly ovate
flowers are small, yellow, on spikes
fruit is a 3-lobed capsule containing white seeds

photos.author: © C.Evans. University of Illinois. Photo take from Invasive.org [Attribution-NonCommercial 3.0 United States (CC BY-NC 3.0 US) https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc/3.0/us/], from Wikimedia Commons
© D.Tenaglia. Missouriplants.com. Photo taken from Invasive.org [Attribution-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported (CC BY-SA 3.0) https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/], from Wikimedia Commons

© C.Evans. University of Illinois. Photo take from Invasive.org [Attribution-NonCommercial 3.0 United States (CC BY-NC 3.0 US) https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc/3.0/us/], from Wikimedia Commons

invasion: native to central-south Asia and Australia
introduced for soil improvement and livestock forage
forms pure stands that can take over entire fields
inhibits the growth of other plants (allelopathic compounds)
reduces native plants in natural areas
behavior: perennial
seeds can remain viable for up to twenty years
can spread vegetatively (fragments)
tolerant of drought and winter temperatures
confusion: None
appearance: erect growth,  1 - 1.5 m tall
leaves alternate along the stem
leave divided into 3 small ones (leaflets) and with awl-shaped spine
leaflets covered with hairs
violet to purple flowers, single or in groups
seeds shiny, slightly flattened

photos.author: ©Fernández García 2005 [Attribution-ShareAlike 2.1 Spain (CC BY-SA 2.1 ES) https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.1/es/deed.en], from Wikimedia Commons

invasion: native to northern and central China and North Vietnam
internationally introduced for ornament, shelter and soil erosion control
widely established
forms dense thickets that displace native vegetation
competes with many plant species for light and space
produces toxins that inhibit the growth of other plants
behavior: fast-growing
prolific fruiting
able to adapt to infertile soils and different altitudes
seeds can be dispersed by the wind, water and road traffic
confusion: A. altissima can be confused with sumacs (Rhus spp.), but they can be distinguished by the small glands on the underside of A. altissima leaves. Young A. altissima may also be confused with black walnut (Juglans nigra) because of the leaves' shape; however, the flowers, seeds and smell are different
appearance: green to pink-reddish curving branches
usually 6-10 m tall
bark is smooth with pale stripes
leaves are compound, can be hairy or not
flowers small and yellow, forming long clusters
male flowers have unpleasant odour
seeds are light reddish-brown, contained in samaras (dry wing-shaped structures to be spread by wind)

photos.author: © van Vuuren 2018 [Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 International (CC BY-SA 4.0) https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0/], from Wikimedia Commons

invasion: native to central and southern Asia
present in northern France, Spain and Balearic Islands, and eastern Europe
introductions were deliberate as control of insect pests
escaped from the cages in the bird trade
threat to indigenous biota, especially on islands, competing with small mammals and birds for nesting hollows
can spread invasive plants
known to carry avian malaria
poses a human health risk carrying mite, and droppings can spread ornithosis and salmonellosis
behavior: walks rather than hop
territorial
omnivorous, eats fruits, berries, grains, flower nectar, insects and spiders
scavenges on street litter, at rubbish dumps and on animal food
chicks and egg predators
both sexes brood and care for the young
roosts in isolated stands of tall trees alone or in groups
believed to pair for life
build cup-shaped nests out of dry grass, twigs and leaves, in tree hollows and crowns,cliffs, and walls buildings
confusion: Common myna could be confused with other members of the genus Acridotheres, most of which are blackish with white wing patches. The crested myna A. cristatellus is almost entirely black with a very prominent tuft of feathers on the forehead
appearance: up to 23-26 cm long
cocoa-brown body colour
head, neck and upper breast of the adult glossy black
head with an erectile crest
undertail coverts, tail tip and outer feathers white color
bill,  skin around the eye, legs and feet bright yellow
male and female have same appearance,  impossible to distinguish in the field
eggs are pale greenish-blue color

photos.author: Invasive P. juliflora in Tamil Nadu, India ©Thamizhpparithi Maari  2011 [Attribution-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported (CC BY-SA 3.0) https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/], from Wikimedia Commons

P. juliflora inflorescences and leaves, Krishna Wildlife Sanctuary (Andhra Pradesh, India) ©J.M.Garg  2009 [Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 International (CC BY-SA 4.0) https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0/], from Wikimedia Commons

invasion: native to Mexico, Central and northern South America
introduced as fuel and fodder species
escaped from cultivation
seeds are spread by grazing animals or water
present on southern and eastern shores of the Mediterranean
outcompetes native vegetation
blocks paths and make whole areas impenetrable
behavior: fast growing
high reproductive potential
highly mobile locally
can survive in areas with very low annual rainfall
exudes a sticky substance to attach the pollen to insects
confusion: P. juliflora could be mistaken with P. glandulosa since both can be invasive in the same type of habitats. Leaves of P. glandulosa are not hairy, flowers are yellow and the legume containing the seeds is straw coloured or tinged with violet
appearance: shrub or small tree 3-12 m high
spreading branches
leaves compound, divided in leaflets (small leaves), can be hairy
produces spines
flowers in cylindric racemes, greenish-white or light yellow
seeds contained in yellow to brown legumes

photos.author: ©J. H. Miller 2011, USDA Forest Service. Photo from Forestry Images https://www.forestryimages.org/ [Attribution 3.0 Unported (CC BY 3.0) https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/], from Wikimedia Commons
© 2010 H. Sullivan and A. Holditch. Picture taken from http://www.mississippiferns.com. All rights reserved.

invasion: native to Asia
cultivated as ornamental
can be transported on clothing, vehicles, animal fur and cut timber
competes with native species in natural areas
alters fire behavoir, easily spreading into canopy trees and wetland
behavior: climbs up to 30 m
can self-fertilize
produces large numbers of very small spores
spores production can take place all year round
disperses over long distances
confusion: None
appearance: vine-like fern
rootstalks with black to reddish-brown hairs
fronds (leaves) alternate, 12 cm long, margins lobulate
fronds surfaces hairless

invasion: native to Africa and South America
introduced as ornamental plant
dispersed locally by the dumping of garden waste
established in some Mediterranean countries
excludes light to other plants
harbours pests and diseases
behavior: perennial
flowering all year
climbing, it grows rapidly into the tops of trees
forms a thick curtain of stems
seeds are transported by wind and water
confusion: C. grandiflorum is very similar to  C. halicacabum, but these two species can be distinguished because C. grandiflorum has large leaves (6-16 cm long) and densely hairy younger stems. C. halicacabum has smaller leaves (4-12 cm long) and finely hairy to almost hairless younger stems. Its flowers are also smaller
appearance: woody vine with numerous lateral branches
stems almost cylindrical, striate, hairless in the adult
leaves alternates with margins deeply serrate
flowers in groups with white and fleshy petals
seeds are black with a white triangular mark
fruits in inflated membranaceous capsules

photos.author: © Kerr 2014 [Attribution 4.0 International (CC BY 4.0) (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/)], from Wikimedia Commons

invasion: originating from New Zealand
introduced by trade with horticultural and garden plants
present in Ireland, Great Britain and the Faroe Islands
likely to spread to northern areas in the Atlantic Region due to global warming
predates on earthworms populations
economic impact on soil fertility and grasslands productivity
behavior: feeds on earthworms
hermaphrodite
egg-laying period from March to July
egg capsules contain an average of 6 juveniles
it migrates to deeper and cooler layers of the soil during the hottest months
habitat: under debris on the soil surface
confusion: A. triangulatus could be confused with other flatworm species but is considerably larger than the native Microplana flatworms in Ireland and Great Britain. The ‘Australian flatworm’, Australoplana sanguinea is similar in body shape but it is orange
appearance: slimy flattened body
up to 10 mm wide and  200 mm in length
brown color with pale marginal fringe
egg capsules up to 4-8 mm, shiny black and ovoid

photos.author: Cortaderia jubata (purple pampas grass); close-up of inflorescence ©Trevor James/Hamilton 2014. Picture taken from CABI. https://www.cabi.org/isc/datasheet/113484#toPictures
Cortaderia jubata at Humboldt Bay National Wildlife Refuge Complex, California, USA ©G. Leppig & A.J. Pickart.  U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service. Public Domain

invasion: native to South America
can easily spread to new countries through seeds trade
introduced as an ornamental and forage, shelter or erosion control
forms dense stands that displace native vegetation
suppresses the growth of young trees
fire hazard in forestry areas
behavior: rapid growth
accumulation of aboveground and belowground biomass
can produce seeds asexually
can germinate and established in a variety of different soils
lifespan 10 to 15 years
confusion: C. jubata is similar to C. selloana. The leaves of C. jubata are shorter than those of C. selloana, not curled at the tip; also dark green on both surfaces. The spikelets of C. jubata are shorter, more flexuous and purplish, while those of C. selloana are of various colours. C. jubata begins flowering in late January, and C. selloana begins flowering in early March
appearance: large tussock grass
leaves near the base and narrow
pyramidal flowers in clusters (panicle), large, and plume-like
pinkish or purplish to white flowers
flower stems up to 3 times higher than the clump of foliage
dark green, 1-cm-wide, drooping leaves

photos.author: Veldt Grass ©J. Kirkhart 2007 [Attribution 2.0 Generic (CC BY 2.0) https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.0/], from Wikimedia Commons
© H. Rose 2013 [Attribuzione 2.0 Generico (CC BY 2.0) https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.0/deed.it], from Wikimedia Commons
Ehrharta calycina flowerhead © H. Rose 2013 [Attribuzione 2.0 Generico (CC BY 2.0) https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.0/deed.it], from Wikimedia Commons

invasion: native to Southern Africa
introduced for pasture and soil stabilization
seeds can be dispersed along roads and highways by agricultural machinery
forms dense stands reducing local plants and invertebrate diversity
increases fire risks
behavior: reproduces mainly by seeds
can spread by rhizome pieces (underground stem)
abundant production of seeds
dispersed mainly by wind or attached to feathers or fur
root growth is rapid and extensive after rains
confusion: E. calycina can be confused with the Panic veldtgrass (E. erecta). E. erecta is 30-60 cm tall and has leaf blades 5-12 cm in length and 4-9 mm in width. The annual veldtgrass (E. longiflora) has leaf blades up to 20 cm long and 10 mm wide
appearance: tussock-forming grass, 30-75 cm tall
flat, green to reddish-purple leaves, 7-20 cm long
stems under the flowers are 5-7 mm long and purplish
flowers in groups (panicle)
fertile spikelets have hairy veins

photos.author: ©Forest & Kim Starr 2003 [Attribution 3.0 Unported (CC BY 3.0) https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/], from Wikimedia Commons
Andropogon virginicus flowerhead ©H.Rose 2006 [Attribution 2.0 Generic (CC BY 2.0) https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.0/], from Wikimedia Commons
©John Ruter, University of Georgia, Bugwood.org  [Attribution-NonCommercial 3.0 United States (CC BY-NC 3.0 US) https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc/3.0/us/], from Wikimedia Commons

invasion: native from eastern North America to northern South America
aggressive colonizer of disturbed soils
causes erosion and alters hydrology
produces toxines inhibiting the growth of others plants
threat to endangered plant species
threat to agricultural systems
behavior: perennial
flowers in the autumn
wind pollinated
attaches to wool and fur, clothing and in mud on machinery
form persistent seed banks
can resprout within 96 hours after a fire
tolerates contaminated soils
confusion: A. virginicus is very similar to other species of Andropogon, requering expert  examination of flowers morphology
appearance: turf-forming grass
green stems, 0.5-2 m tall
leaves are green, hairless or sparse hairs
flowers in clusters
sessile spikelets 3.5 to 3.8 mm

photos.author: The aquatic fern, Salvinia molesta, photographed in Hawai‘I ©Eric Guinther 2000 [Attribution 2.5 Generic (CC BY 2.5) https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/], from Wikimedia Commons
© Barry Rice 2009 [Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported (CC BY-NC-SA 3.0) https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-sa/3.0/], from Wikimedia Commons

invasion: native to south-eastern Brazil
spreads within aquatic systems by wind, water floods and animals
introduced as ornamental, and unintentionally on boats and aquariums
can cause human health problems as host of mosquitoes
prevents the passage of boats
behavior: perennial
rapid growth
rapid vegetative reproduction
prefers stagnant or slow moving water
habitat: flood canals, artificial lakes and hydro-electric facilities
confusion: S. molesta can be confused with S. natans. Egg-beater-shaped hairs on the upper surface of the floating leaves of S. molesta, allow to distinguish it from the European native S. natans. The ends of the ‘beater’ are not joined together in S. natans. S. natans is also a smaller species
appearance: free-floating aquatic fern
mat-forming
stems irregularly branched and hairy
leaves in whorls of three, rounded, with a distinct midvein
submerged part traps air bubbles
sporocarps (reproductive structure) hairy, globose, located on lower or submersed leaves

photos.author: Plotosus lineatus at Bunaken National Park ©Hectonichus 2012 [Attribution-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported (CC BY-SA 3.0) https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/], from Wikimedia Commons
Plotosus lineatus school ©Hectonichus 2012 [Attribution-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported (CC BY-SA 3.0) https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/], from Wikimedia Commons
© R. Ketabi & S. Jamili 2016. Tehran University, Kish International Campus. Photo from Aquatic Commons,  http://aquaticcommons.org/id/eprint/21036

Plotosus lineatus (Pez gato) en la Sala Humboldt del Aquarium Finisterrae  ©Drow male 2008 [Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 International (CC BY-SA 4.0) https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0/], from Wikimedia Commons

invasion: native to the Red Sea and Indo-Pacific region
lessepsian species (coming from the Red Sea to the Mediterrean through Suez Canal)
not yet present in the European Union
present in the Mediterranean coast of Israel, Lebanon and Egypt
likely to be introduced
can be found in the marine aquarium trade
behavior: feeds on benthic invertebrates and small fish
adults solitary or in small groups
juveniles form dense groups moving over the substrate
male constructs the nest under rocks and debris, and guards the eggs
confusion: In the Mediterrean it will be distinguised from all other species because of the barbels
appearance: elongated shape , 10-25 cm long
brown body with two narrow white stripes
4 pairs of barbels
head round, large and broad
jaw with distinct lips
teeth visible when mouth closed
two dorsal fins, second one long and confluent with anal fin
strong spine at pectoral fin origin

photos.author: © Alvesgaspar 2008 [Attribution-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported (CC BY-SA 3.0) https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/], from Wikimedia Commons

invasion: originating from southwestern Australia
widely planted around the Mediterranean basin for fodder, fuelwood, sand stabilization, windbreak and as an ornamental
modifies ecosystems hydrology, fire and nutrient regime and successional patterns
forms monocultures
reduces native biodiversity by competition for the resources and shading
behavior: highly adaptable to different environments
pioneering in disturbed areas
fast-growing
drought-tolerant
prolific seed production
propagules can remain viable for more than one year and re-sprout
reproduces asexually
confusion: A. saligna is sometimes confused with A. pycnantha, but it can be distinguished from all other commonly introduced Australian acacias from the phyllodes (the part that connects the stem with the leaves), being larger and straight to sickle-shaped in A. saligna, and any confusion can be resolved with the use of a simple field guide
appearance: dense, multi-stemmed shrub or single stemmed tree 2-6 m tall
smooth and grey to red-brown bark, becoming fissured with age
dark green to blue-green leaves with conspicuous midribs, 8-25 cm long
flowers heads globular, bright yellow
seeds dark brown to black and shiny, contained in pods 8-12 cm long

photos.author: ©Yoshikazu Takahira 2007 [Attribution-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported (CC BY-SA 3.0) https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/], from Wikimedia Commons
© E. Romani 2018 [Attribuzione - Non commerciale - Non opere derivate 4.0 Internazionale (CC BY-NC-ND 4.0) https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/deed.it], from Wikimedia Commons

invasion: native to Russia
introduced in Europe as ornamental
present in southern France, western Hungary and northern Italy
displaces native vegetation by out-competing for resources
its pollen is allergenic
behavior: rapidly-growing
forms dense stands
seeds dispersed by wind and water
male and female flowers are on separate plants
blooms from mid to late summer
confusion: H. scandens can be differenciated from the native H. lupulus because H. scandens is annual while H. lupulus is perennial, and its leaves are lighter green
appearance: vine shape
stems grow up to 5-8 m
leaves opposite, palm shaped, 5 to 6 cm long
stems and leaves have rough hooked hairs
female flowers are bigger and pale green

photos.author: © Barrette 2012 [Attribution-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported (CC BY-SA 3.0) https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/], from Wikimedia Commons
©B. Dupont 2014 [Attribuzione - Condividi allo stesso modo 2.0 Generico (CC BY-SA 2.0) https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0/deed.it], from Wikimedia Commons

invasion: native to eastern North America
established in regulated rivers in Iberia
introduced as pet in private ponds and for sport fishing
preys on fish eggs and endemic mollusk species
behavior: fast growing
high reproductive potential
lives in groups
males build the nest near the shore, and guard the eggs
females produce up to 1,000 eggs
disperses via natural drift in water courses
confusion: None
appearance: disc-like body
18-23 cm in length
body color orange, green, yellow, or blue speckles on an olive back
colours are intensified in breeding males
sharp spines in the dorsal and anal fins

photos.author: © Kurt Stüber 2005 [GNU Free Documentation License], from Free Software Fundation
©Krzysztof Ziarnek, Kenraiz 2016 [Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 International (CC BY-SA 4.0) https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0/deed.en], from Wikimedia Commons
©K. Kurt Stüber 2005 [GNU Free Documentation License], from Free Software Fundation

invasion: native of tropical and sub tropical America from Mexico to Argentina
introduced mainly as an aquarium plant
stem fragments and seeds can accidentally spread in mud attached to animals, boats, trailers and lawnmowers
excludes other plants and the animals that rely on them
affects recreational activities, drainage channels, irrigation and navigation
behavior: perennial
grows very quickly
covers water bodies with a floating mat
reproduces by seeds and from stem fragments
seeds can be spread in mud attached to animals or machinery
tolerant of shade
long life
habitat: humid tropic and warm temperate habitats
surface of slow moving or stationary water bodies
confusion: G. spilanthoides can be confused with other species which grow in or near water, and with the invasive Alternanthera philoxeroides (alligator weed). G. spilanthoides has serrated leaf margins whereas alligator weed has rounded margins. Leaves of G. spilanthoides are fleshier and less rigid than those of Hygrophila corymbosa
appearance: emergent herb
forms rounded bushes or mats of pale-green stems
leaves are dark green, arranged in opposite pairs
numerous, white, ball-shaped flowers
seeds are yellow-brown and small
roots can develop from leaf veins or segments of the stem

invasion: native to Eastern North America
intentional introduction for cultivation and human consumption
can outcompete native amphibians
the chorusing of large males sometimes considered as noise pollution
reports of severe allergic reactions in some people who ingested bullfrogs
behavior: during metamorphosis it converts from vegetarian tadpole to carnivore that can eat any animal, even juveniles of its own species
hibernates to withstand below-freezing temperatures
only the adult males produce the frog call
habitat: freshwater systems: lakes, ponds, marshes, generally in shallow still water
confusion: adult specimens very distinct but juvenile bullfrogs can easily be mistaken for other species
appearance: one of the largest frog species, reaching 18 cm long and 0.5 kg weight
olive to brownish with random dark spots on dorsal and lateral body parts, while abdominal side white
head flat with conspicuous eardrums
skin smooth
limbs with inter-digital swimming webs

photos.author: © I, Pkuczynski 2007[GFDL (http://www.gnu.org/copyleft/fdl.html) or CC-BY-SA-3.0 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/) from Wikimedia Commons]
© Доктор рукиноги (Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 3.0 Unported)

invasion: originating from south-eastern Siberia
introduced for hunting and fur
high capability to spread to new areas, it may also spread to northern areas due to global warming
suspected for predation of native birds and frogs
important vector of rabies and parasites
behavior: excellent swimmer
nocturnal
omnivorous
high reproductive potential
monogamous, the male participates in warming and guarding the pups when the female is foraging
can hibernate in areas where winters are harsh
habitat: open landscapes, especially damp meadows with abundant undergrowth
can visit gardens searching for fruits and berries
confusion: The facial mask resembles that of the raccoon (Procyon lotor), they can be easily distinguished by the raccoon’s striped tail. Carcasses tracks of roadkill animals  can be confused with those of badgers (Meles meles).
appearance: black facial mask
small rounded ears
body color varies from yellow to grey or reddish
black hairs on the back, shoulders and dorsally on the tail
legs, feet and chest dark
short tail covered with thick hair

photos.author: © David Blank (Creative Commons Attribution-Noncommercial-Share Alike 3.0 Unported License)
© David Blank (Creative Commons Attribution-Noncommercial-Share Alike 3.0 Unported)

invasion: native to Southeast Asia
introduced as a pet
can cause severe debarking of trees
can outcompete native squirrels for food and nest sites
behavior: herbivorous species, consumes leaves, flowers, fruits, seeds
commonly found in tree hollows
constructs leaf nests above the ground
young individuals disperse from their natal areas and establish their own home ranges
confusion: distinction from other squirrels can be difficult
can be distinguished by the absence of black and buff stripes along the flanks
appearance: a medium-sized tree squirrel, up to 50 cm long (including the tail)
usually brownish on the upper body, reddish on the belly, often some black on the tail
coloration can vary depending on geography

invasion: native to the eastern main Caucasian ridge
introduced as an ornamental plant and for honey production
overwhelms native species
can cause riverbank erosion
toxic to humans; skin burning after physical contact
behavior: develops large dense stands
perennial
flowers during summer
habitat: terrestrial, mostly found in urban areas: gardens, roadsides, parks, but also in grasslands and near rivers and lakes
confusion: closely related and very similar to Heracleum mantegazzianum
their distinction requires specialist expertise
appearance: herb up to 3 m high
firm stem, sparsely hairy, with purple blotches
leaves broad, up to 50 cm long, with upper surface hairless and below slightly hairy
flowers white to pinkish, in compound umbels
seeds egg-shaped, densely hairy when unripe

invasion: native in South America
escaped from zoos
no ecosystem impacts are known but it could become an important predator or competitor with native species
behavior: its name ‘coati’ comes from native American Indian words meaning ‘belt’ and ‘nose’, referring to the way coatis tuck their nose into their belly while sleeping
omnivorous, eating invertebrates and fruits
males solitary, but females travel in groups of up to 30 individuals
usually active during the day, spends its nights sleeping in trees
spends much of its time foraging in trees, but can also be found on the ground
its elongated snout is very useful for searching crevices and holes for food
habitat: terrestrial: various kinds of forests and wetlands
confusion: None
appearance: similar to raccoon, up to 1 m long including tail
reddish-brown fur, whitish belly
elongated, flexible snout
white spots around its eyes
ears short and rounded
banded tail with yellow rings

photos.author: Microstegium vimineum © James H. Miller & Ted Bodner, Southern Weed Science Society, Bugwood.org (Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported license)
© Arthur Haines, New England Wild Flower Society (All Rights Reserved)
© Leslie J. Mehrhoff, University of Connecticut, Bugwood.org (Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported)
© Leslie J. Mehrhoff, University of Connecticut, Bugwood.org (Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported)

invasion: native to Asia
seeds spread as contaminants on shoes, clothes, machinery, soil
outcompetes native plants
can alter soil properties
may decrease arthropod abundance and diversity
used in the past as packing material for porcelain
behavior: annual
seed propagated
shade tolerant
rapid growth
may form dense monospecific stands
flowering and fruiting in late summer
habitat: variety of disturbed sites: roadsides, railroads, ditches, damp fields
confusion: can be distinguished from other grasses by its thin, pale green, tapered leaf blades, and by the silvery line in the middle of the upper leaf surface
appearance: decumbent delicate grass
pale green in color but during fall turns to pale-purple
leaves alternate, lanceolate, with pointed apex
a silvery line runs down the middle of the upper leaf surface
multiple flowers grouped in racemes, terminal or arising from the leaf axils

photos.author: Floating Pennywort © Snowdonia National Park Authority

invasion: native to North and South America
introduced in Europe through ornamental and aquarium trade
can outcompete native aquatic plants
blocks water control structures and can lead to flooding events
can create problems to boat navigation and water recreational uses
behavior: a fast growing species
forms extensive floating mats on the water surface
thrives under highly eutrophic conditions
prefers sun exposure and can resist to European winters, since its submerged parts can persist under ice cover
habitat: stagnant and slowly running water of rivers, streams, ponds, lakes, ditches
confusion: similar with other species of the genus
can be distinguished by its leaf margin which is split to central petiole, and by its overlapping marginal lobes
appearance: aquatic stoloniferous plant, floating on water
stems horizontal, bear nodes at rather regular intervals
dense mats of roots at each node as well as elongated erected stalks
leaves kidney-shaped of various sizes (2-15 cm)
flowers small, 3 mm in diameter, whitish to yellowish, borne in small clusters of 5-13
fruits brownish, ovoid-ellipsoid, strongly flattened dorsally

photos.author: © Chucholl C. (Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 3.0 Unported)
© André Karwath aka Aka (Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 2.5 Generic)

invasion: native in North America
one of the most widely distributed crayfish species in the international pet trade
introduced after pet aquaria releases
threatens native crayfish due to competition and transmission of the crayfish plague
may have significant impact on fish populations
behavior: only females exist which lay unfertilized eggs that develop into genetically uniform offspring (parthenogenesis)
high reproductive potential: one single specimen is sufficient to create a new population
no males have ever been recorded
fast growing species
lives in open water during most of its life and burrows only under extreme conditions
polytrophic omnivore
habitat: freshwater: rivers, lakes, swamps, drainage ditches, fish ponds
confusion: distinguished from other crayfish species by the color pattern (a marble pattern with dark lateral horizontal stripes through the carapace and pleon)
appearance: medium-sized crayfish up to 10 cm long
distinct, appealing marbled color pattern
dark lateral horizontal stripes through the carapace
dorsal carapace smooth, but lateral surface slightly granulated
acute cervical spine present at each side and the cephalic section, bearing tubercles
chelae relatively small, being two times shorter than the carapace length

photos.author: © Bill Chan Photography (2014) billcanada.wix.com/photography (All Rights Reserved)

invasion: native to North America
introduced into Europe for fur farming
damages vegetation through grazing
may threaten invertebrate communities
burrowing can weaken riverbanks causing them to collapse
damage to agriculture, railways, dams, dikes, fish farms
could host parasites affecting humans and domestic animals
behavior: territorial
fast growing with high rate of reproduction
well adapted for swimming, spends most of its time in water
can create two types of habitation: burrows in river banks or lodges
mainly nocturnal
essentially herbivorous, sometimes omnivorous
confusion: distinct from nutria (Myocastor coypus) by its flattened and hairless tail (rounded and hairy in nutria)
appearance: large amphibious rodent, 40-70 cm long
broad head and short rounded ears
fur from grey to brown, with underside slightly paler
fur dense and waterproof
tail hairless and flattened laterally, as long as the head and body

photos.author: © Didier Descouens Museum of Toulouse (Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 4.0 International)
© Didier Descouens Museum of Toulouse (Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 4.0 International)

invasion: native in Southeast Asia
introduced in France through boxes of pottery from China
highly aggressive predator of native honey bees
could be dangerous for man by inducing a life-threatening allergic reaction or after multiple stings, similar to the native hornet stings
behavior: hunts honey bees and other insects
active in April-November
makes very large nests, to 75 cm long, in tall trees in urban and rural areas
only one mated queen is enough to start a new colony and initiate further spread
ability to thermoregulate their nests to a constant temperature of around 30°C
vigorously defends its hunting territory, chasing off any rivals
habitat: the paper nests are usually built in tree canopies, or occasionally in buildings, and very rarely near the ground
confusion: distinguished by the European hornet by its smaller size, the characteristic yellow legs, and the dark abdomen with only one yellow band
never active at night whereas European hornets may be
appearance: dark brown velvety body
characteristically dark abdomen with a distinctive yellow band on the fourth segment
head black and face yellow
yellow tipped legs
smaller than the native European hornet, workers to 2 cm long

photos.author: © Greg Tee, Amsterdam, The Netherlands (Creative Commons Attribution 2.0 Generic)
© Steve Garvie, Dunfermline, Fife, Scotland (Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 2.0 Generic)

invasion: native to Africa
escaped from zoos
feeds on several threatened species (insects, batrachians, etc.)
feeds on eggs of several protected bird colonies
competes successfully for nest sites with native bids
suspected of spreading disease since it frequently forages in rubbish dumps and slurry pits
behavior: often forming large groups
breeds in colonies up to hundreds of pairs
carnivorous with a tendency to omnivory
feeds on insects, fishes, frogs, molluscs, crustaceans
nomadic, able to change its breeding sites to suit environmental conditions
nests often closely aggregated in trees, bushes and on ground near water
habitat: grasslands, marshes, estuaries, farmyards, rubbish dumps, suburban areas
confusion: None
appearance: large white bird, to 90 cm long and to 120 cm wingspan
head and neck black, without feathers
long black legs
bill long, curved, black

photos.author: Photo from www.nobanis.org, photographer: Merike Linnamägi

invasion: native in northwestern USA
used for restocking plague-devastated European crayfish
significant grazing pressure on macrophytes, aquatic insects, snails, benthic fishes and amphibian larvae
aggressive competitor to native crayfish species
threat to the native noble crayfish due to transmission of the crayfish plague fungus
behavior: high adaptability to a wide range of environments
fast-growing with high fecundity
opportunistic polytrophic feeder, consumes also detritus
constructs burrows in river and lake banks
habitat: small streams to large rivers, lakes, brackish waters
Europe so far: in almost all European countries
confusion: can be confused with the noble crayfish (Astacus astacus) but distinguished by:
the lack of spines on the shoulders of carapace
the white-turquoise patch on the claw junction
appearance: large crayfish, to 16 cm long
smooth reddish-brown exoskeleton
no spines on the shoulders of carapace
claws robust, smooth, bright red
white-turquoise patch on the claw junction

invasion: native to Caucasus
introduced into Europe as ornamental
competes and replaces most native plants
soil erosion
serious dermatological effects on skin (avoid touching it)
behavior: perennial
forms monospecific stands
prolific seed production
flowers only once, when 3-5 years old
flowering from June to August
once it has flowered, the plant dies
habitat: well-lit, nutrient rich and moist soils
common along roadsides, river banks, railways, woodland fringes, grasslands
ruderal sites such as rubbish dumps and waste grounds

stems often purple spotted

invasion: native to Southeast Asia
introduced through intentional (mainly horticulture) and accidental releases
kills mostly all plants that it overgrows
a significant pest, reduces native species biodiversity and completely modifies the ecosystem
can cover and smother orchard and plantation crops causing economic damages
behavior: growth can be very rapid
can attach and climb most surfaces
seeds are dispersed by wind, animals, water
its large roots act as water reservoirs, permitting the plant to withstand drought
symbiotic relationship with nitrogen-fixing bacteria
habitat: terrestrial: forests, agricultural areas, grasslands, riparian zones
urban areas (roads, telephone poles, abandoned buildings)

highly invasive (competitive) and persistent weed, threatens native species
negative economic impacts in agriculture

potential vector of fungal and virus plant diseases

flowers produce copious amounts of nectar
flowering usually from June to August

invasion: native to South America
introduced through escapes or releases from fur farms
declines native plants through herbivory
can destroy bird nests and preys on eggs
their burrows penetrate and damage river banks, dykes and irrigation facilities
responsible for economic damages to agricultures

mainly herbivorous
fast colonizers
can breed throughout the year

impressive jumpers

appearance: a medium-sized tree squirrel, up to 70 cm long

widely used as ornamental because of its beautiful flowers

invasion: native in Asia, from Iraq to Myanmar, and from Pakistan to India

invasion: native to southeast China and Taiwan
introduced deliberately for hunting or escaped from zoos
grazing can effect diversity of plant species, with indirect effects on fauna

invasion: native in the USA

prominent yellow to red patches on each side of the head
carapace and skin are olive brown with yellow stripes and spots
males are usually smaller than females and have a long, thick tail

photos.author: © Justin Newman, Dallas, Texas (All Rights Reserved)

invasion: native to north-eastern Mexico and south-central USA
intentional introduced for aquaculture, but can spread also by anglers for local consumption, and as bait
widely available in the aquarium trade
outcompetes the native European crayfish (family Astacidae) through transmission of the crayfish fungus plague Aphanomyces astaci
degrades riverbanks because of its burrowing activity
accumulates heavy metals and toxins produced by Cyanobacteria, and can transfer them to its consumers, including humans
behavior: tolerant to a wide range of environmental conditions
benthic and omnivorous, feeding on insects, larvae, detritus, etc., with a preference for animal matter
burrows during periods of drought or cold
tolerates dry periods of up to 4 months
exhibits territorial behaviour and is aggressive with its own species
habitat: prefers small but permanent freshwater systems: swamps, ditches, sloughs, ponds
avoids streams with a strong flow
confusion: None
appearance: crayfish to 12 cm long
body shape cylindrical
conspicuously granular carapace with marginal spines
adults dark red, orange, or reddish brown
chelae narrow and long, with bright red tubercles and spines
sexually active males with distinct grasping hooks on the ischia, used to hold females during copulation

photos.author: Topmouth Gudgeon Taxidermy specimen - GBNNSS © Crown Copyright 2009
Topmouth Gudgeon - Matt Brazier - Environment Agency © Crown Copyright 2009

invasion: native in East Asian, including Japan and parts of Korea and China
introduced in Europe with stocking material of herbivorous fishes imported from China
feeds on juvenile stages of many locally valuable native fish species
vector of infectious diseases threatening both native and farmed fish in Europe
probably contributed to a decrease in abundance of some native cyprinids
behavior: zooplanktivorous
able for rapid expansion
saline intolerant, not occurring in brackish waters
males guard the eggs until hatching, and aggressively drive away other fish
habitat: freshwater systems: shallow lakes, carp ponds, irrigation canals, ditches
confusion: None
appearance: small fish, up to 11 cm long
color: back grey, light sides, yellowish-green to silver belly
elongated body, slightly flattened on sides
head flattened in its anterior part
mouth clearly in top position
lateral line complete, running in the middle of sides

photos.author: © Andy Reago & Chrissy McClarren (Creative Commons Attribution 2.0 Generic)

invasion: native in Central and North America
introduced in Europe through intentional (for hunting and fur) and accidental introductions
common in the pet trade
capability of adjusting to a wide range of habitats and climatic conditions
can damage native fauna through predation and competition
susceptible to a number of diseases, such as roundworms, which can have public health consequences
behavior: mostly nocturnal
omnivore, its diet can be very diverse
excellent climbing and swimming abilities
can survive harsh winters by entering a dormant period
females remain in their natal area
habitat: almost all terrestrial habitats, but especially those adjacent to water
confusion: similar to Nyctereutes procyonoides, but the latter has 4-toed footprint (5-toed in raccoon) and does not have a ringed tail
appearance: a medium-sized mammal with characteristic black mask
fur grey, but occasionally blackish or reddish, it turns whitish on the flanks and legs
limbs rather short
tail bushy with 4-7 blackish rings

photos.author: © Christian Fischer (Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 3.0 Unported)
Elodea nuttallii © Christian Fischer (Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 3.0 Unported license)

invasion: native to North America
introduced into Europe as an aquarium plant
can form dense submerged beds
can outcompete native plants
blocks pipes and drainage systems
impedes boating, fishing and affects recreation activities
behavior: perennial
rapid growth
fragments easily dispersed by currents, attached to machinery, footwear, fishing equipment
tolerant to disturbance such as oil pollution
stimulated by fertilization with nitrogen
habitat: still waters such as shorelines of lakes, reservoirs, ponds, along rivers and streams, wetlands, canals, ditches
able to grow in turbid, highly eutrophic waters as well as in clear waters
generally shallow water, 3 to 5 m depth
confusion: smaller, paler, leaves shorter and narrower than Elodea canadensis
similar to Egeria densa but the latter has longer leaves in whorls of 4–6
similar to Lagarosiphon major, but the latter has very strongly recurved leaves and in spirals whereas those of E. nuttallii are in whorls
appearance: submerged aquatic plant
rooting at nodes
stems long and slender, often freely branched
leaves pale green, typically in whorls of 3, lanceolate, often recurved with folded margins
floating flowers, white, at the tips of long stalks

photos.author: © Jen Goellnitz (Flickr, goellnitz) (Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-NoDerivs 2.0 Generic)
© Pacific Southwest Region USFWS (Creative Commons Attribution 2.0 Generic)
© Sandy Cole (Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 3.0 Unported)
© Peter Massas (Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 2.0 Generic)

invasion: native in North and Central America
introduced in Europe by escapes and accidental releases from breeding farms
poses a threat to the endangered white-headed duck (Oxyura leucocephala) through hybridization and competition
behavior: excellent divers
omnivorous, feeding on small invertebrates, seeds and parts of aquatic plants
nests are floating structures made of marsh plants
seasonal dispersal in resident UK populations
confusion: None
appearance: a small diving duck, up to 45 cm long and 700 g in weight
long (sometimes erect) tail
males with a bright blue bill, black head, white cheeks and a reddish body
females with brownish body, darker bill and a brown line along the cheeks

photos.author: Impatiens glandulifera © Udo Schmidt from Deutschland (Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 2.0 Generic license)
Impatiens glandulifera - Himalayan Balsam © GBNNSS Crown Copyright 2009
Impatiens glandulifera - leaf detail © Rob Hille (Public Domain)
Impatiens glandulifera - flower detail © André Karwath aka Aka (Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 2.5 Generic license)

invasion: native to Himalaya
introduced in Europe as ornamental
may reduce native species diversity
can exclude native plants from pollination
facilitates river bank erosion
behavior: annual, present in spring-summer
rapid growth
forms dense stands
exclusively seed propagated
the flowers have the highest sugar nectar production in Europe
attracts numerous insect pollinators, especially bees
habitat: moist and relatively nutrient rich habitats
common in railways, waste grounds, urban areas, roadside ditches
confusion: Impatiens parviflora is smaller and has pale-yellow flowers
I. noli-tangere and I. capensis are both smaller in size
I. balsamina  has single flowers
appearance: erect plant up to 3 m high
stems reddish, branched, hollow, hairless
leaves opposite, glabrous, lanceolate to obovate, sharply serrated
inflorescences in groups of 2-14 flowers
flowers white, pink or purple

photos.author: Myriophyllum heterophyllum © Leslie J. Mehrhoff, University of Connecticut, Bugwood.org (Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported license)
Myriophyllum heterophyllum © Leslie J. Mehrhoff, University of Connecticut, Bugwood.org (Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported license) (2)
© Leslie J. Mehrhoff, University of Connecticut, Bugwood.org (Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported)

invasion: native to southeast USA
introduced through aquarium trade
outcompetes native aquatic plants
the weed mats prevent water flow, reduce sunlight and oxygen availability
impedes swimming, boating and fishing
negatively impacts drainage and irrigation systems, hydropower and drinking water resources
behavior: perennial
forms dense mats
spreads primarily via fragmentation
flowering rare, from May to October
can tolerate hot summer as well as cold winter temperatures
habitat: lakes, ponds, rivers, swamps, mudflats, wetlands, irrigation channels
confusion: very similar to other Myriophyllum species, distinguished by characters of flowers and fruits
can be recognized by the undivided, serrate emergent leaves when present
appearance: freshwater submersed green plant
stems stout, dark red to brown, up to 1 m long
submersed leaves feather-like and pinnate, into whorls of 4-5, dissected into 7-11 leaflets
emergent leaves during late summer, stiff in texture
inflorescence is an emerged spike ca. 30 cm long, consisting of small red flowers in whorls of 4

photos.author: © ALAN SCHMIERER (Creative Commons CC0 1.0 Universal Public Domain Dedication)

invasion: native in North America
introduced in Europe through accidental or deliberately aquarium releases
can result in significant shift from clear to turbid waters
can displace native fish and crayfish and reduces macroinvertebrate and macrophyte abundance and biodiversity
carriers of crayfish plague which is lethal to the native European crayfishes
behavior: highly mobile, fecund and tolerant of a wide range of environmental conditions
tends to hide in crevices under or between rocks rather than making burrows
omnivorous, consumes a variety of live and dead animal and plant material
cannot tolerate polluted waters
habitat: freshwater: streams, rivers, canals, ponds, marshes, lakes
prefers warm waters of moderate turbidity with rocky-gravel substrates
confusion: may be confused with other crayfishes, but can be distinguished by its broader, flattened tuberculate chela
appearance: crayfish to 11 cm long
carapace smooth
color reddish-brown to olive-brown
chelae broad, flattened, tuberculate, rather blue
chelae often have dark specs and orange or reddish tips

photos.author: © Yuriy Kvach (Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 3.0 Unported)

invasion: native to Asia: Russia, China, North Korea
commonly kept in aquaria and used as live bait
exhaust the entire food supplies, and can outcompete native species for the same food resources
can have an adverse overall impact on native aquatic fauna
behavior: can tolerate poorly oxygenated water
able to survive in dried out or completely frozen water bodies by digging itself into mud where it hibernates
voracious predator, feeds on wide variety of invertebrates, tadpoles and fish
males guard the eggs and pelagic larvae
habitat: freshwater fish: lakes, ponds, marshes, rivers
prefers stagnant rivers with dense underwater vegetation and muddy substrate
confusion: can be distinguished from other similar freshwater fishes by its two dorsal fins: the first with 6-8 simple rays, the second with 2-3 simple and 8-12 branched rays
appearance: a freshwater small/medium fish up to 25 cm long
robust scaled body
coloration rather dark; varies from greenish-olive to brownish-grey depending on substrate
on the dorsal and lateral sides there are dark irregular spots and blotches
large mouth with caniform teeth
two dorsal fins: the first with 6-8 simple rays, the second with 2-3 simple and 8-12 branched rays
males during spawning period become black with bright green spots on body

photos.author: © André Karwath aka Aka (Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 2.5 Generic)
© André Karwath aka Aka (Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 2.5 Generic)

invasion: native to South America
commonly sold for aquaria and aquatic gardens
outcompetes native aquatic plants
can cause water deoxygenation
impedes boats and clogs drainage ditches
provides habitat for mosquitos
behavior: prefers good light, warm and high-nutrient environments
can form dense mats
small fragments root easily in mud to establish new colonies
in Europe all plants are female
habitat: slow-moving freshwater habitats: ponds, lakes, canals
confusion: the emergent small “fir trees” distinguishes it from similar species
appearance: submerged / emergent aquatic plant
stems elongate to 2 m long, suspended in the water column and/or floating
leaves finely pinnately divided, feather-like, in whorls of mostly 5
both submersed and emergent leaves, the latter resembling small “fir trees”
flowers emerge from axils of leaves

photos.author: Pennisetum setaceum - clumps © Frank Vincentz (Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 3.0 Unported license)
Pennisetum setaceum © Forest & Kim Starr (Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported license) (2)
Pennisetum setaceum © Ziegler175 (Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 4.0 International license)
Pennisetum setaceum - inflorescence © John Tann from Sydney, Australia (Creative Commons Attribution 2.0 Generic license)
Pennisetum setaceum © John Tann from Sydney, Australia (Creative Commons Attribution 2.0 Generic license) (2)
Pennisetum setaceum - ripening seeds © Mullookkaaran (Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 3.0 Unported license)

invasion: native to North Africa
introduced through horticultural trade
reduces native species diversity
extremely inflammable, increasing the intensity and spread of fire
unpalatable to cattle except for young shoots
behavior: perennial
fast growing
establishes dense symmetrical clumps
seed and vegetatively propagated
flowers usually between March and September
habitat: disturbed areas: roadsides and railroad embankments
open sunny areas with well-drained soils
confusion: similar to Cenchrus advena but the latter has wider leaf blades without a thickened mid-vein
close to Pennisetum villosum but the latter has white seed heads
appearance: clump-forming grass
leaves slender, arching, linear, up to 60 cm long
flowers rose-colored, grow as dense, bristly panicles on stalks up to 1.2 m high
seed heads pink to purple

invasion: native to Middle East, probably Iran
introduced as an ornamental plant
can outcompete native plants and become a plague
its bristles can cause eczema after physical contact; after exposure sunlight should be avoided
the seeds are used in Persian cooking
behavior: perennial species
prefers moist and nutritious soils
flowers during summer
habitat: terrestrial, common in gardens, parks and near urban areas
confusion: easily confused with other Heracleum species (such as H. mantegazzianum)
can be distinguished by the color of the stems’ base and the shape of the leaflets’ lobes
appearance: herb, up to 1.5 m high
many stems, bristly haired, red-brown in their base
leaves alternate, stalked, pinnate in 5 segments, with lower side haired, glabrous on top
leaflets lobed, with blunt-toothed margins
flowers white, forming a compound umbel
small seeds, obovate, 8 mm long
